CO oxidative esterification is crucial in converting inorganic CO into organic oxygenated compounds within C1 chemistry and technology. However, understanding the structure-activity relationship underlying this reaction remains limited, primarily due to the entanglement of the Pd's geometric and electronic structures, which complicates selectivity control in practical applications. In this work, we design four Pd-based catalysts using the Al(111) motif to investigate their catalytic performance in CO oxidative esterification through density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Firstly, the larger lattice parameter of Al weakens horizontal Pd–Pd interactions while enhancing the vertical stability of Pd. Secondly, the electronic structure of Pd is locally regulated via charge transfer between subsurface and surface Pd, driven by their differences in work function. Our results indicate that the relative activity between CC coupling for dimethyl oxalate (DMO) and CO coupling for dimethyl carbonate (DMC) is primarily influenced by Pd's electronic effects, as revealed by energy barrier decomposition analysis. Thus, focusing on the regulation of Pd's electronic effects may offer a new strategy for controlling the selective oxidation esterification of CO. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords C1 chemistry and technology CO oxidative esterification Geometric structure Electronic structure Structure-activity relationship Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction CO is an important platform molecule in C1 chemistry and technology [1,2]. CO oxidative esterification to dimethyl oxalate (DMO) or dimethyl carbonate (DMC) is crucial in producing high-value organic oxygen-containing compounds from syngas [3–6]. In industrial processes, Pd-based catalysts perform excellent but high cost due to the low Pd utilization and high Pd loading, and many challenges lie in achieving high stability [7–10], activity, and especially the selectivity at ultra-low Pd loading in this reaction [11]. That's because the economic viability is further reduced by the energy consumption required for the substantial product separation and purification [12]. Although many experiments for CO oxidative esterification on Pd-based catalysts have been reported, the origin of Pd's catalytic role needs to be clarified. Many fundamental issues, such as the assembled forms of Pd, are highly controversial. The first mechanism suggests that metallic Pd is conducive to DMO production, while oxidized Pd tends to favor DMC production [13]. Guo et al. prepared two model Pd/a-Al2O3 catalysts using nano-preparation techniques. They confirmed that Pd, in its metallic form assembled in Pd(111), played a pivotal role in the high DMO activity [14]. Building upon this observation, Lu et al. fine-tuned the surface hydroxyl concentration of Al fiber, thereby amplifying DMO activity through the synergistic interplay of hydroxyl groups with metallic Pd [15]. Similarly, Guo et al. augmented the oxygen vacancy concentration in Pd-based spinel-like ZnAlO catalysts, thereby reducing the valency state of Pd and enhancing DMO activity [16]. In contrast, Yasushi Yamamoto unearthed differing results, showcasing that Pd in a highly oxidative state within a PdCl2/AC catalyst exhibited remarkable reactivity towards DMC [17]. Further insights were gained by Guo et al., who discovered that palladium acetylacetonate complex accelerated the step where Pd δ + reoxidized to Pd(II), resulting in higher DMC activity [18]. Theoretically, Yao et al. used two-dimensional C2N as a model to regulate the valence state of Pd in the catalyst by adjusting the N/B ratio. Intriguingly, They found that Pd in the metallic state in Pd2@4B-C2N favored the generation of DMO, and Pd in the oxidized state in Pd2@C2N favored the generation of DMC [19]. The second mechanism suggests aggregated Pd favors DMO production, and isolated Pd favors DMC production. Yao et al. employed DFT and in situ IR experiments to unveil the reaction mechanism of CO oxidative esterification on Pd(111) in nanoparticle-aggregated form [20]. They pinpointed a crucial step facilitating DMO synthesis from CO and methyl nitrite (MN), namely the association of two adsorbed COOCH3 via CC coupling. Guo et al. successfully prepared Pd/ZnMgAl-LDH (layered double hydroxides) catalysts with ultra-low Pd loading in the cluster-aggregated form through the atomic layer deposition (ALD) technique [21]. The observed enhancement in DMO was ascribed to introducing Zn2+ ions into the MgAl-LDH support, promoting covalent metal-support interaction (CMSI) via forming PdZn bonds. In contrast, Guo et al. produced the Pd/NaY zeolite catalyst in the form of mononuclear-isolated Pd(II) centers by adopting an ultrasonic-assisted ammonia evaporation approach. The catalyst was beneficial for DMC production via the Eley–Rideal (E–R) mechanism [22]. In the similar approach, Wang et al. found an isolated form of a single Pd atom supported on the Pd/TiO2 catalyst, achieving a remarkable enhancement for DMC [23]. The DFT result demonstrated that the steric hindrance effect exerted by individual atoms enhanced the yield of the desired DMC product by prohibiting further reaction to the byproduct. However, many cases cannot be divided into the above mechanisms. Guo et al. undertook a solvothermal synthesis, yielding two model catalysts with HKUST (The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology)-1 as the framework. They found that the isolated Pd(II) in PdCu/HKUST-1 without neighboring metal methoxy carbonyls intermediates favored DMC via the E–R mechanism, paired-Pd(II) in Pd/HKUST-1 catalyzed DMO formation through adjacent COOCH3 coupling, operating under the Langmuir–Hinshelwood (L–H) mechanism. Notably, Pd in two catalysts existed in the isolated form and high oxidized valence state [24]. Similarly, Jiang et al. delved into the influence of Pd nanoparticle positioning within the metal-organic framework (MOF) UiO (Universitetet i Oslo)-66 on DMO and DMC production. Intriguingly, Pd in two catalysts were in the aggregated form and low metallic valence state [25]. When the Pd nanoparticles were situated on the external surface of the UiO-66, DMO emerged as the predominant product. Conversely, the integration of Pd nanoparticles into UiO-66 led to DMC becoming the primary product. In view of the above situation, we might reclassify the mechanism by which Pd acts on the reaction in another way. CO oxidative esterification occurs on the active Pd surface, and the catalytic performance is susceptible to the Pd's geometric and electronic structure [26–28]. However, the alterations in Pd geometric structure also concurrently induces changes in its electronic structure, thereby complicating the comparison and definitive identification of the predominant factor influencing the reaction [29,30]. Two essential effects aptly capture the influence of these two structures on the reaction: the geometric effect, primarily impacting adsorption conformation due to the competition between adsorbates and Pauli repulsion [31,32], and the electronic effect, mainly influencing the strength of adsorption [33]. In this work, geometric effects involving specific Pd ensembles (single atom, clusters, and nanoparticles), primarily changing co-adsorption energies due to the competition between adsorbates. Electronic effects originating from the change in electron distribution states of Pd due to charge transfer, hybridization and dipole effects, primarily impacting the bonding strength between the Pd and the adsorbate. There is yet to comprehend the two Pd's effects well. Two crucial questions need to be solved: (i) Who is playing the dominant role, the geometric or the electronic effect? (ii) How do we regulate the Pd-based catalysts to achieve selective CO oxidative esterification? Wang et al. showed that compressive effect in PdML/Cu(111) [34], PdML/Co(111) [35], and PdML/Ni(111) [35] had no significant impact on Pd's reactivity towards DMO. Meanwhile, tensile effect in PdML/Ag(111) [36] and PdML/Al(111) [34] enhanced Pd's reactivity towards DMC and DMO, respectively. As a late transition metal, the d-band center of Pd moves towards the fermi level with tensile effect, enhancing reactivity towards reactants [37–39]. Given the complexity of the Pd's structure in this work, we first use the Al(111) substrate to maintain the active Pd(111)’s geometric structure horizontally. We are then modulating the Pd's electronic structure vertically by the difference in work function between the subsurface and surface Pd (4.5–5.1 eV for Cu, 4.2–4.7 eV for Ag, 5.2–5.6 eV for Pd, 5.1–5.9 eV for Pt, and 5.1–5.4 eV for Au) to establish a structure-activity relationship [40,41]. This work reveals that the Pd's electronic effect governs the reaction path via modulating the relative activity between CC coupling for DMO and CO coupling for DMC thermally and kinetically in CO oxidative esterification. Herein, we present a novel strategy for controlling the selective oxidation esterification of CO. When DMO dominates as the primary product, introducing a high work function support or metal to place Pd in an electron-deficient state, elevating the valence state of Pd promotes the formation of DMC. Conversely, when DMC takes precedence as the main product, introducing the support or metal with a low work function to achieve an electron-rich state for Pd, reducing the valence state of Pd tends to favor the production of DMO. 2 Computational methods and models The DFT theoretical calculations are performed using the VASP software [42,43]. The pseudopotential part employs the plane-wave PAW method [44,45], and the exchange-correlation part utilizes the GGA-PBE functional [46]. The weak van der Waals interactions are corrected using the DFT-D3 approach [47,48]. A vacuum layer with a thickness greater than 15 Å is applied in the Z direction to avoid periodic interactions. Spinning polarization is enabled during the geometry optimization process, and the energy cutoff is set to 450 eV. The (2 × 3 × 1) Monkhorst-Pack k-point is used, with energy convergence criteria below 1 × 10−5 eV and force convergence criteria below 0.03 eV Å−1. The CI-NEB method is initially employed for optimization to obtain the preliminary transition state [49,50], followed by the dimer method to get the final transition state [51,52]. The force convergence criteria for this optimization is set to 0.05 eV Å−1, and only one imaginary frequency along the reaction direction was allowed. All state energies undergo zero-point energy (ZPE) correction. In this work, the lattice constant of Al is set to 4.050 Å, consistent with experimental results. The pure Al(111) model consists of a p(4 × 3) supercell with six layers. On this basis, the outermost layer of Al is replaced by Pd, and the subsurface Al is replaced by Cu, Ag, Au, or Pt, named P d ML / C u ML /Al(111), P d ML / A g ML /Al(111), P d ML / A u ML /Al(111) and P d ML / P t ML /Al(111), respectively. Moreover, the adsorption energy of CO on p(4 × 3) supercell is compared with those on larger p(4 × 4) and p(5 × 4) supercell, respectively, which are −78.9 kJ/mol, −80.2 kJ/mol and −81.8 kJ/mol on the P d ML /Al(111), −122.9 kJ/mol, −119.5 kJ/mol and −122.5 kJ/mol on the P d ML / C u ML /Al(111), −137.6 kJ/mol, −131.6 kJ/mol and −135.0 kJ/mol on the P d ML / A g ML /Al(111), −148.5 kJ/mol, −139.7 kJ/mol and −144.6 kJ/mol on the P d ML / A u ML /Al(111), −162.6 kJ/mol, −151.8 kJ/mol and −161.2 kJ/mol on the P d ML / P t ML /Al(111), demonstrating that no obvious changes occur on the adsorption energy as the supercell size enlarges and the p(4 × 3) supercell model is sufficient for our calculation. On the other hand, the electronic structure of the outermost surface Pd layer is primarily influenced by the neighboring subsurface. Increasing the thickness of the subsurface has a minimal impact on the electronic structure of Pd. Taking P d ML / C u ML /Al(111) as an example, varying the thickness of Cu layers (1–4) shows negligible changes (0.17 e for one layer, 0.16 e for two layers, 0.16 e for three layers, and 0.16 e for four layers compared with the ground state Pd via Bader charge analysis [53,54]. Further, increasing the thickness of Pd layers may reduce its utilization efficiency, adding to the cost of the catalyst. Other kinds of subsurface is not applied to, such as Co (5.0 eV) and Ni (5.0–5.3 eV), as their work functions are close to Cu (4.5–5.1 eV) [41]. Considering the limited availability of pure metal substrates, we can extend this scenario to supported catalysts using the methodology proposed by Professor Lu [55]. By gaining a deep theoretical understanding of the influence of Pd's structure on reactivity, further designing industrially relevant supported catalysts for CO selective oxidation esterification under more complex circumstances will benefit significantly. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Electronic property, adsorption and stability Due to differences in the work functions of various metals, electron transfer occurs at the interface between Pd and the subsurface to achieve a balance of Fermi level [56]. In Fig. 1 , Bader charge analysis of P d ML /Al(111), P d ML / C u ML /Al(111), P d ML / A g ML /Al(111), P d ML / A u ML /Al(111), and P d ML / P t ML /Al(111) five catalysts reveals that the average charge of surface Pd relative to the ground state Pd is 0.93 e, 0.17 e, 0.11 e, 0.04 e, and 0.03 e, respectively. At the same time, the lateral PdPd bond length remains constant at 2.863 Å. CO oxidation esterification involves the reactants’ adsorption, conversion, and desorption. The adsorption strength of CO during the reactants’ adsorption step serves as an initial indicator for the overall reaction. In Fig. 2 , the adsorption energies of CO at the Pd top position on the five catalysts are −78.9 kJ mol−1 [34], −122.9 kJ mol−1, −137.6 kJ mol−1, −148.5 kJ mol−1, and −162.6 kJ mol−1, respectively. The association of the non-transition sp-electron metal Al between the d-band transition metal Pd induces a significant charge transfer [57]. However, the noticeable broadening of the Pd's d-band width of the five catalysts, with the Pt catalyst exhibiting the lowest adsorption energy, cannot be adequately explained using the d-band center theory [58]. Therefore, a COHP [59,60] analysis using LOBSTER [61] package was employed to assess the strength of the Pd-C bond, reflecting the adsorption properties of CO. The ICOHP values for the five catalysts are −0.83 eV, −0.94 eV, −0.97 eV, −1.02 eV, and −1.12 eV, respectively (only up values are listed here due to negligible differences with down values and consistent trends). The trend in ICOHP values aligns with the changes in CO adsorption strength, indicating that the Pd in catalyst P d ML /Al(111) gains more electrons to fill the antibonding states when interacting with CO, significantly reducing the adsorption strength. Furthermore, the binding energy of Pd for the five catalysts is more negative relative to Pd(111) (−1.03 eV per atom), with the values of −2.53 eV, −2.06 eV, −1.58 eV, −1.53 eV, and −1.62 eV, respectively. It indicates that the tensile strain stabilizes Pd at the longitudinal interface. Moreover, as the charge transfer increases, the above stabilizing effect becomes more evident at the interface. All five metals (Al, Cu, Ag, Au, and Pt) exhibit a face-centered cubic structure, exposing stable low-index (111) crystal planes. The lattice mismatch relative to Al motif is reasonable (4.0 % for Pd, 12.8 % for Cu, 4.7 % for Ag, 3.7 % for Au, and 4.1 % for Pt) and the overall structure is in a thermodynamically relatively stable state. The AIMD simulations, perform at 500 K with the settings of the time step at 2.0 fs for a total period of 7 ps, are used to evaluate the thermodynamic stability over P d ML /Al(111), P d ML / C u ML /Al(111), P d ML / A g ML /Al(111), P d ML / A u ML /Al(111), and P d ML / P t ML /Al(111) catalysts. No significant geometrical distortion is observed during the whole AIMD simulations (Figs. S5–S9), suggesting their thermodynamic stability. 3.2 Catalytic activities of P d ML / C u ML /Al(111), P d ML / A g ML /Al(111), P d ML / A u ML /Al(111) and P d ML / P t ML /Al(111) catalysts toward DMO and DMC formation The initial reactants for the reaction are CO and methyl nitrite (MN). Due to the facile catalytic decomposition of MN into OCH3 on the surface of Pd catalysts, substituting MN with OCH3 can simplify the entire process of CO oxidative esterification. Based on previous literature reports [20], the COCO self-coupling pathway is thermodynamically unstable on the Pd catalyst surface. Therefore, this paper primarily discusses three reaction pathways: COOCH3 COOCH3 self-coupling, COCOOCH3 dicarbonyl insertion, and OCH3 COOCH3 CO coupling in Scheme 1 . Different pathways involve various types of CO and CC couplings. To facilitate the description of the CO oxidative esterification process, different types of C and O are labeled. The same part is the COOCH3 (C1O2) coupling in R1, where the generation of DMO is mainly influenced by COCOOCH3 (C1C3) and COOCH3 COOCH3 (C1C3) couplings, while the generation of DMC is influenced by the OCH3 COOCH3 (C1O4) coupling. The relative reactivity of key CO and CC couplings in crucial steps affects the selectivity of DMO and DMC, and the overall CO and CC reactivity influences the overall activity of DMO and DMC. The structural parameters (IS, TS and FS), reaction barriers, and reaction energies involved in the P d ML / C u ML /Al(111), P d ML / A g ML /Al(111), P d ML / A u ML /Al(111), and P d ML / P t ML /Al(111) catalysts are summarized in Tables 1 and S1. 3.2.1 Catalytic activity for DMO and DMC generation on the catalyst of P d ML / C u ML /Al(111) In Path 1 of Fig. 3 , IS2 involves the coadsorption of OCH3 and CO on P d ML / C u ML /Al(111). The neighboring absorbed CO (via C atom) and OCH3 (via O atom) bond to the Pd top and bridge sites, exhibiting intermolecular repulsion in an end-on configuration. This configuration is accompanied by the release of 296.3 kJ/mol of heat. The COOCH3 intermediate (via C atom) in IS3 appears on the Pd top site after C1O2 coupling via TS1, resulting in a gradual reduction of the C1O2 distance from 3.673 Å in IS2 to 1.355 Å in IS3. R1 involves overcoming an energy barrier of 32.3 kJ/mol for the first COOCH3 formation, releasing 27.2 kJ/mol of heat. Subsequently, another adsorbed CO and OCH3 co-bind to hollow and bridge sites in IS4, leading to an exothermic reaction (−376.0 kJ/mol). The second COOCH3 intermediate is formed through C3O4 coupling via TS2 with a barrier of 79.9 kJ/mol and heat absorption of 49.3 kJ/mol, resulting in COOCH3 COOCH3 in IS5. Finally, a barrier of 108.9 kJ/mol in R3 is overcome to form a new C1C3 bond (1.545 Å) in DMO from the old C1C3 bond (3.653 Å) of IS4 via TS3, utilizing C1C3 self-coupling and releasing 11.0 kJ/mol of heat. In Path 2, the COOCH3 formed in R1, along with the adsorbed OCH3 and CO, generates OCCOOCH3 (via C atom) by C1C3 self-coupling between COOCH3 and CO via TS4. This process involves an energy barrier of 181.2 kJ/mol and a reaction energy of 124.2 kJ/mol. The C1C3 distance decreases from 3.653 Å in IS4 to 1.542 Å in IS6. Finally, a slightly lower activation energy of 17.7 kJ/mol in R5 is required for the formation of DMO in FS2 through C3O4 coupling via TS5, releasing 88.4 kJ/mol of heat, with a C3O4 distance variation from 3.812 Å in IS6 to 1.343 Å in FS2. In Path 3, the COOCH3 formed in R1 with the adsorbed OCH3 generates DMC in FS3 by C1O4 coupling via TS6. This pathway involves a low energy barrier of 164.8 kJ/mol and a reaction energy of −92.5 kJ/mol, resulting in a reduction of the C1O4 distance from 6.616 to 3.006 Å. In summary, considering energy barriers, R3 in Path 1 exhibits the lowest energy barrier, leading to DMO as the main product. 3.2.2 Catalytic activity for DMO and DMC generation on the catalyst of P d ML / A g ML /Al(111) In the structural evolution of P d ML / A g ML /Al(111), a parallel sequence unfolds as observed in Fig. 4 , akin to the progression seen in P d ML / C u ML /Al(111). In Path 1, the initial coadsorption energy of OCH3 and CO is −312.5 kJ/mol, closely resembling the value (−296.3 kJ/mol) observed in P d ML / C u ML /Al(111). During R1, OCH3 reacts with CO via C1O2 coupling, generating a new C1O2 bond in IS3 (dC1O2 = 1.353 Å) through TS1 (dC1O2 = 1.993 Å), with IS2 (dC1O2 = 3.998 Å) as the starting point. This process is exothermic at −15.6 kJ/mol, requiring a modest energy input of 33.6 kJ/mol. The second coadsorption energy (−373.6 kJ/mol) of OCH3 and CO post-R1 is more negative, attributed to changes in CO adsorption mode on Pd, transitioning from the top site to the hollow site. During C3O4 coupling, an energy barrier of 48.8 kJ/mol is overcome to form the second COOCH3 intermediate. In R2, the transformation from IS4 (dC3O4 = 3.459 Å) to IS5 (dC3O4 = 1.359 Å) via TS2 (dC3O4 = 1.938 Å) requires 26.3 kJ/mol of heat. The conversion from IS5 (dC1C3 = 4.446 Å) to FS1 (dC1C3 = 1.541 Å) in R3 produces the final product DMO, necessitating an activation energy of 81.9 kJ/mol and contributing 7.8 kJ/mol of energy. In Path 2, OCCOOCH3 in IS6 (dC1C3 = 1.542 Å) stems from continuous carbonylation from CO. The second adsorbed CO attacks COOCH3 via C1C3 through TS4 (dC1C3 = 1.854 Å) from IS4 (dC1C3 = 3.629 Å), requiring a barrier of 134.6 kJ/mol and yielding a reaction energy of 115.1 kJ/mol. Another C3O4 coupling is needed for the reproduction of the final product DMO, with the relevant structures evolving from IS6 (dC3O4 = 3.788 Å) through TS5 (dC3O4 = 2.210 Å) to FS2 (dC3O4 = 1.344 Å). This step demands 17.6 kJ/mol to overcome the barrier and releases 78.2 kJ/mol of heat. In Path 3, the critical chain for DMC formation involves C1O4 coupling, with OCH3 migrating to COOCH3 through the evolution of surface species from IS4 (dC1O4 = 6.143 Å) through TS6 (dC1O4 = 1.957 Å) to FS3 (dC1O4 = 1.353 Å). A driving energy of 23.9 kJ/mol is crucial to propel the process, resulting in the release of 102.0 kJ/mol of heat after DMC formation. Notably, the energy barriers for DMO and DMC are concurrently reduced, particularly in the DMC pathway, showcasing superior DMC catalytic performance. 3.2.3 Catalytic activity for DMO and DMC generation on the catalyst of P d ML / A u ML /Al(111) In the case of P d ML / A u ML /Al(111), a parallel structural evolution is observed relative to P d ML / A g ML /Al(111), as illustrated in Fig. 5 . Within Path 1, the initial coadsorption energy of OCH3 and CO is −314.6 kJ/mol, closely approximating the value of −312.5 kJ/mol in P d ML / A g ML /Al(111). During R1, OCH3 undergoes a C1O2 coupling with CO, forming a new C1O2 bond in IS3 (dC1O2 = 1.355 Å) via TS1(dC1O2 = 2.081 Å) from IS2 (dC1O2 = 3.389 Å). This process is exothermic at −25.7 kJ/mol, requiring a low energy input of 24.0 kJ/mol. The second coadsorption energy (−388.46 kJ/mol) of OCH3 and CO after R1 is even more negative, reflecting changes in CO adsorption mode on Pd, transitioning from the top site to the hollow site. In the C3O4 coupling, an energy barrier of 73.0 kJ/mol is overcome to advance the reaction towards forming the second COOCH3 intermediate. R2 involves the transformation of IS4 (dC3O4 = 3.829 Å) to IS5 (dC3O4 = 1.360 Å) via TS2 (dC3O4 = 1.913 Å), requiring 44.4 kJ/mol of heat. In R3, the transformation from IS5 (dC1C3 = 3.607 Å) to FS1 (dC1C3 = 1.539 Å) via TS3 (dC1C3 = 2.036 Å) results in the generation of the product DMO, with an activation energy of 116.8 kJ/mol and an additional input of 16.7 kJ/mol. Path 2 involves the generation of OCCOOCH3 in IS6 (dC1C3 = 1.541 Å) through continuous carbonylation from CO. The second adsorbed CO attacks COOCH3 through C1C3 via TS4 (dC1C3 = 1.904 Å) from IS4 (dC1C3 = 3.626 Å), necessitating a barrier of 165.5 kJ/mol and releasing a reaction energy of 124.1 kJ/mol. Another C3O4 coupling is required for the reproduction of the final product DMO, with the relevant structures evolving from IS6 (dC3O4 = 3.765 Å) through TS5 (dC3O4 = 2.197 Å) to FS2 (dC3O4 = 1.341 Å). This step demands 21.9 kJ/mol to cross the barrier, releasing 63.6 kJ/mol of heat. In Path 3, the critical chain for DMC formation involves C1O4 coupling. OCH3 migrates to COOCH3, and the evolution of surface species progresses from IS4 (dC1O4 = 6.230 Å) through TS6 (dC1O4 = 2.033 Å) to FS3 (dC1O4 = 1.356 Å). A driving energy of 40.6 kJ/mol is crucial to promote the process, resulting in the release of 79.1 kJ/mol of heat after DMC formation. Compared to the case with P d ML / A g ML /Al(111), there is an increase in the energy barrier for DMC, but the main product remains DMC. 3.2.4 Catalytic activity for DMO and DMC generation on the catalyst of P d ML / P t ML /Al(111) In Path 1, the coadsorption of OCH3 and CO in IS2, with a C1O2 distance of 4.421 Å, occurs on the Pd hollow site, releasing a substantial heat (453.3 kJ/mol) compared to P d ML / C u ML /Al(111) (296.3 kJ/mol), as depicted in Fig. 6 . However, a more pronounced energy barrier (137.4 kJ/mol) than that of P d ML / C u ML /Al(111) in R1 is necessary to generate the COOCH3 intermediate, positioned on the Pd top site, by forming a new C1O2 bond (dC1O2 = 1.356 Å) in IS3 through TS1 (dC1O2 = 1.951 Å) via C1O2 coupling from IS2 (dC1O2 = 4.421 Å), absorbing heat of 94.5 kJ/mol. In IS4, the coadsorbed energy of the second OCH3 and CO (−410.1 kJ/mol) is slightly larger than that in IS2 due to repulsion from the adsorbed COOCH3. The formation of COOCH3 COOCH3 in IS5 (dC3O4 = 1.368 Å) is achieved after the C3O4 coupling via TS2 (dC3O4 = 1.841 Å) from IS4 (dC3O4 = 3.374 Å). R2 is an endothermic reaction (51.5 kJ/mol), with an activation energy of 77.4 kJ/mol. The DMO in FS1 (dC1C3 = 1.539 Å) is formed by C1C3 self-coupling via TS3 (dC1C3 = 2.013 Å) from IS5 (dC1C3 = 3.689 Å). R3 is also an endothermic procedure (44.9 kJ/mol) and requires a higher activation energy of 136.6 kJ/mol. For the C1C3 double carbonyl coupling in Path 2, the already formed COOCH3 from R1 attacks the adsorbed CO to create the intermediate OCCOOCH3 via TS4 (dC1C3 = 1.887 Å) from IS4 (dC1C3 = 3.745 Å) to IS6 (dC1C3 = 1.541 Å), requiring energy barriers and reaction energies of 177.6 and 135.0 kJ/mol, respectively. At the end of Path 2, DMO in FS2 (dC3O4 = 1.339 Å) is synthesized through C3O4 coupling via TS5 (dC3O4 = 2.241 Å) with a lower energy barrier (35.4 kJ/mol) from IS6 (dC3O4 = 3.861 Å), extracting heat of 37.9 kJ/mol. For the C1O4 coupling in Path 3, the related COOCH3 in IS4 (dC1O4 = 6.261 Å) selectively attacks the adsorbed OCH3 to generate DMC in FS3 (dC1O4 = 1.354 Å) via TS6 (dC1O4 = 1.873 Å). A much lower energy barrier (50.6 kJ/mol) must be overcome in R6 than that of P d ML / C u ML /Al(111) (164.8 kJ/mol), releasing heat of 59.1 kJ/mol. In comparison with the P d ML / C u ML /Al(111) catalyst, it is evident that C1C3 coupling in R4 of Path 2 is the rate-controlling step for DMO production. The main product transitions from DMO to DMC, but the overall energy barrier is relatively high with low DMC activity. 3.2.5 Microkinetic analysis DMC and DMO, weakly adsorbed on the surface, are assumed to desorb from the reaction system rapidly, and the reverse reactions (R3, R5, and R6) are neglected. The mean-field approximation is employed to characterize the reaction details of all elementary reactions in CO oxidative esterification, outlined in Table 2 . Experimental conditions, such as P C H 3 ONO = 200 kPa, P CO = 280 kPa, and T = 375–415 K, are considered, and the microkinetic analysis details are described in the Supporting Information. The resulting reaction equilibrium constants, rate constants, surface coverage, and formation rate are presented in Tables 3–5 . 3.2.6 Discussion The kinetics, thermodynamics, and microkinetics analysis show that DMO is the predominant product for P d ML / C u ML /Al(111) through COOCH3 COOCH3 self-coupling in Path 1. Path 1 is also the optimal reaction pathway for synthesizing DMO for the other catalysts in the CO oxidative esterification process. However, the energy barrier for synthesizing DMC in P d ML / A g ML /Al(111), P d ML / A u ML /Al(111), and P d ML / P t ML /Al(111) catalysts is significantly lower than that for DMO, leading to DMC becoming the primary product through OCH3 COOCH3 coupling in Path 3. In the catalytic conversion of CO and OCH3 to DMO or DMC, the inherent structure of the catalyst governs the strength of interactions between the catalyst and adsorbed species (reactants, transition states, intermediates, and products). The underlying driving force for these changes is the reoptimized distribution of electrons. Detailed information on the electron changes in the catalyst and adsorbate interactions is provided in Table S2 and Figs. S1–S4. In Path 1 for synthesizing DMO, the adsorbates in P d ML / C u ML /Al(111) (+1.8 × 10−2 e, 108.9 kJ/mol), P d ML / A u ML /Al(111) (+5.0 × 10−2 e, 118.6 kJ/mol), and P d ML / P t ML /Al(111) (+5.4 × 10−2 e, 136.6 kJ/mol), adopting similar configurations in IS5 (COOCH3 in top adsorption) and TS3. The largest charge variation occurs in P d ML / P t ML /Al(111), corresponding to the highest energy barrier of CC coupling to DMO. However, in P d ML / A g ML /Al(111) (−1.3 × 10−1 e, 81.9 kJ/mol), where one COOCH3 is in bridge adsorption in IS3, the behavior differs significantly from the above three catalysts. The first item in parentheses represents the charge variations in adsorbates from IS5 to TS3. Where + indicates that the absorbates gain the electrons from the substrate, while - refers to that the absorbates release the electrons back to the substrate. The second item refers to the energy barrier in R3. Similarly, in Path 6 for synthesizing DMC, the adsorbates in P d ML / C u ML /Al(111) (−1.5 × 10−1 e, 164.8 kJ/mol), P d ML / A g ML /Al(111) (−1.0 × 10−1 e, 23.9 kJ/mol), and P d ML / P t ML /Al(111) (−1.2 × 10−1 e, 50.6 kJ/mol), adopting similar configurations in IS4 and TS6 (the CO group in COOCH3 faraway from CO). The least charge variation in P d ML / A g ML /Al(111) refers to the lowest energy barrier of CO coupling to DMC. While in P d ML / A u ML /Al(111) (−1.4 × 10−1 e, 40.6 kJ/mol), the CO group in COOCH3 towards CO in IS6, more charge variations refer to P d ML / P t ML /Al(111), but lower energy barrier for CO coupling. The second item refers to the energy barrier in R6. Thus, the configuration of the adsorbate significantly affects the charge state of the adsorbate, and the charge variations in absorbates from IS to TS couldn't reflect the catalysis tendency solely for different Pd-based catalysts due to the coupling of the inherent Pd's geometric and electronic structures. R3 entails the association of two COOCH3, while R6 involves the association of COOCH3 and OCH3 (a general association reaction form: A + B → AB). To quantitatively describe the impact of the geometric and electronic effects on the reaction to answer the first question, we performed the energy barrier decomposition for reaction processes R3 and R6, as illustrated in Scheme 2 [62,63]. We partitioned the transition state (TS) barrier into two components: One is the deformation energy (def), driving the transition of A (B) from the initial state to the transition state, named E A d e f ( E B d e f ), mainly arising from the variation of the adsorbate chemisorption energy due to local electronic effect. The other one is the interaction energy transformation ( E int ) between A and B from the initial state to the transition state, containing bonding competition and Pauli repulsion between A and B due to the geometric effect. In R6, the deformation energy of COOCH3 is E A d e f , and the deformation energy of OCH3 is E B d e f . As shown in Table 6 , with P d ML / C u ML /Al(111) as the reference, the energy changes induced by the geometric effect in R3 and R6 are relatively small, less than 20 kJ/mol. Both COOCH3 and OCH3 only have one valency, similar to the CH3 + H → CH4, indicating that their interaction does not lead to significant competitive effects. In R3, involving the CC coupling of two of the same COOCH3, their slightly different deformation energy may stem from distinct spatial configurations of COOCH3 in TS3 due to its polyatomic nature and flexibility conformations. However, from IS4 to TS6 in R6, among P d ML / A g ML /Al(111), P d ML / A u ML /Al(111), and P d ML / P t ML /Al(111), relative to P d ML / C u ML /Al(111), changes in E A d e f exceeding 100 kJ/mol. In contrast, the changes in E B d e f is less than 10 kJ/mol, suggesting that the electronic effect significantly influences the stability of the transition state via COOCH3, reducing the energy barrier of CO coupling for DMC. In order to answer the second question, we systematically analyze the Bader charge of surface Pd (an essential factor in Pd's electronic effect) together with other catalysts in Fig. 7 . In P d ML /Al(111), P d ML / C u ML /Al(111), and P d ML / A g ML /Al(111), the Bader charge of Pd varies from 0.93 e, 0.17 e, to 0.11 e. Especially in P d ML / C u ML /Al(111), and P d ML / A g ML /Al(111), Cu (1.90) and Ag (1.93) have lower electronegativity relative to Pd (2.20), enabling Cu and Ag to donate electrons to Pd, thereby creating an electron-rich state for Pd. The intrinsic driving force behind this electron transfer behavior is the difference in work functions between the metals (5.23 eV for Pd(111), 4.714 eV for Cu(111), and 4.368 eV for Ag(111) [41]). Fig. 1 shows a significant electron transfer at the interface, while Fig. 2 indicates that more electrons fill the d-band of Pd, stabilizing it. Additionally, the center of the d-band of Cu is further from the Fermi level compared to that of Ag. Hence, in the P d ML / C u ML /Al(111) and P d ML / A g ML /Al(111), the Pd's electronic effect is affected by a charge transfer effect where the filling of the d-band changes due to the charge transfer between Pd and other metal (Cu or Ag). In R6, the reaction involves the coupling of COOCH₃ and OCH₃ to produce DMC, with the entire process influenced by the ensemble effect of Pd. In P d ML / C u ML /Al(111) and P d ML / A g ML /Al(111), the COOCH₃ is adsorbed in a top position, while OCH₃ is in a bridge position. A total of three Pd atoms are directly involved in the reaction. The overall charge difference of Pd in the Cu and Ag motif is 0.18 e. Additionally, as shown in Table S2, the charge difference after the adsorption of COOCH₃ and OCH₃ exceeds 0.4 e. It results in a significant kinetic reduction in the energy barrier for DMC, leading to the transformation of the reaction product from DMO to DMC. In P d ML / A g ML /Al(111), P d ML / A u ML /Al(111), and P d ML / P t ML /Al(111), the Bader charge of Pd changes from 0.11 e, 0.04 e to 0.03 e, with a minor variation in the DMC energy barrier. Thermodynamically, it optimates the overall energy change during the reaction process, with the best reactivity for DMO and DMC in Ag according to the reaction energy profile and microkinetics analysis. In R1 for Pt and Au motif, Bader charge analysis shows negligible charge transfer between Pd and other metals (Pt or Au) in Fig. 1. The 2D electron localization function (ELF) slice along the (1, 0, −1) surface is shown in Fig. S10, where the two top Pd and other metals (Pt or Au) layers’ ELF < 0.5 represent non-local state [64]. In Fig. 2, different d-band shapes and widths appear in the P d ML / A u ML /Al(111) and P d ML / P t ML /Al(111), which may lead to differences in the degree of orbital coupling and the bonding strength between them and the adsorbates. Based on the above results, the electrons are not localized and reorganized without causing significant charge transfer, and the Pd's electronic effect is affected by a hybridization effect due to the change in the overlap between orbitals. During the co-adsorption of CO and OCH3, the adsorption configuration of CO changes from sub-stable top to hollow and bonds directly with more Pd sites. As shown in Table S2, the charge distinction after the adsorption of CO and OCH₃ exceeds 0.2 e in the P d ML / A u ML /Al(111) and P d ML / P t ML /Al(111). The adsorption configurations and charge variations result in a marked variation in energy from the initial state to the transition state. From the energy barrier decomposition for reaction processes R1, the energy barrier caused by electronic and geometric effects in P d ML / A u ML /Al(111) is 19.8 kJ/mol and 4.2 kJ/mol, in P d ML / P t ML /Al(111) is 120.3 kJ/mol and 17.1 kJ/mol, respectively. Using Ag(111) as the substrate, further increasing the Pd's Bader charge from 0.03 e in P d ML /Ag(111), 0.16 e in Pd4Ag8/Al(111) to 0.20 e in Pd1-Ag(111) results in a significant decrease in the DMO energy barrier, causing the reaction product to shift from DMC to DMO. However, simultaneously introducing strain (inducing Pd's geometric effect) and similar charge transfer (causing Pd's electronic effect) in PdML/Cu(111) (0.14 e), P d ML /Co(111) (0.16 e), and P d ML /Ni(111) (0.13 e), relative to the Pd(111) (0.03 e), the overall reactivity towards to DMO generation exhibits minimal changes, possibly due to the coupling between Pd geometric (G) and electronic (E) effects (two possible combinations: E+, G− or E−, G+, where G+ (G−) indicates that geometric effects increase (decrease) the energy barrier, while E+ (E−) follow the same definition). 4 Conclusions In this work, the relative activity between COOCH3 COOCH3 (C1C3) coupling for DMO in Path 1 and OCH3-COOCH3 (C1O4) coupling for DMC in Path 3 in CO oxidative esterification is mainly controlled by the Pd's electronic effect in P d ML / C u ML / Al ( 111 ) , P d ML / A g ML /Al(111), P d ML / A u ML /Al(111), and P d ML / P t ML /Al(111) catalysts. When the catalyst favors DMO in P d ML / C u ML / Al ( 111 ) and changes the Pd's electronic structure via charge transfer to increase the Pd oxidation state in P d ML / A g ML /Al(111), it shifts towards favoring DMC. Conversely, when the current catalyst tends to DMC in P d ML / A g ML /Al(111), altering the Pd's geometric structure by tuning the assembled form of Pd, growing Pd's electron-rich state, causes it to transition towards favoring DMO in Pd1-Ag(111). The association of the low valency intermediate such as COOCH3 and OCH3 does not lead to significant competitive effects, resulting in minor influence of Pd's geometric effect. The work focuses on Pd's electronic effect as a descriptor to achieve highly selective catalysis in CO oxidation esterification. coredata.dc:description: CO oxidative esterification is crucial in converting inorganic CO into organic oxygenated compounds within C1 chemistry and technology. However, understanding the structure-activity relationship underlying this reaction remains limited, primarily due to the entanglement of the Pd's geometric and electronic structures, which complicates selectivity control in practical applications. In this work, we design four Pd-based catalysts using the Al(111) motif to investigate their catalytic performance in CO oxidative esterification through density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Firstly, the larger lattice parameter of Al weakens horizontal Pd–Pd interactions while enhancing the vertical stability of Pd. Secondly, the electronic structure of Pd is locally regulated via charge transfer between subsurface and surface Pd, driven by their differences in work function. Our results indicate that the relative activity between CC coupling for dimethyl oxalate (DMO) and CO coupling for dimethyl carbonate (DMC) is primarily influenced by Pd's electronic effects, as revealed by energy barrier decomposition analysis. Thus, focusing on the regulation of Pd's electronic effects may offer a new strategy for controlling the selective oxidation esterification of CO.
